articles.headline: iZon Webcam Sees a Lot, but Misses a Little
articles.snippet: Stem’s iZon is a webcam you can watch from anywhere and don’t need a computer. But its software is bug-ridden.
articles.abstract: Stem’s iZon is a webcam you can watch from anywhere and don’t need a computer. But its software is bug-ridden.
articles.lead_paragraph: Consumer tech is filled with enduring mysteries.

articles.headline: Patent Bill Viewed as Bailout for a Law Firm
articles.snippet: A provision in a bill before the Senate could get an influential law firm off the hook for a possible $214 million malpractice payment.
articles.abstract: A provision in a bill before the Senate could get an influential law firm off the hook for a possible $214 million malpractice payment.
articles.lead_paragraph: A bill to overhaul the patent system that is before the Senate contains a provision that could get an influential law firm off the hook for a possible $214 million malpractice payment.

articles.headline: In a New Libya, Ex-Loyalists Race to Shed Ties to Qaddafi
articles.snippet: After months of war, Libyans have set aside their grievances against functionaries of the Qaddafi government who now work for the rebel government.
articles.abstract: After months of war, Libyans have set aside their grievances against functionaries of the Qaddafi government who now work for the rebel government.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — Khalid Saad worked for years as a loyal cog in Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s propaganda machine, arranging transportation to ferry foreign journalists to staged rallies, ensuring that they never left their hotels without official escorts and raising his own voice to cheer the Libyan leader.

articles.headline: Romney and Perry Clash, Drawing Lines in G.O.P. Sand
articles.snippet: The debate was the first time the Republican contenders shared a stage since Gov. Rick Perry opened his campaign in August.
articles.abstract: The debate was the first time the Republican contenders shared a stage since Gov. Rick Perry opened his campaign in August.
articles.lead_paragraph: SIMI VALLEY, Calif. — The fight for the Republican presidential nomination began narrowing into an intense and ideological battle at a debate here Wednesday night, with Gov. Rick Perry of Texas and Mitt Romney sharply clashing over Social Security, health care and each other’s long-term prospect against President Obama.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Adam Nagourney

articles.headline: Once a Leader, Yahoo Now Struggles to Find Its Way
articles.snippet: As the rest of the Internet moved on to social networks and mobile devices, Yahoo failed to keep up.
articles.abstract: As the rest of the Internet moved on to social networks and mobile devices, Yahoo failed to keep up.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Yahoo has been one of the most-visited sites on the Internet since its glory days as a Web portal. Yet as the rest of the Internet moved on to social networks and mobile devices, Yahoo has failed to keep up.
articles.byline: By Claire Cain Miller and Verne G. Kopytoff

articles.headline: Blunt E-Mail Raises Issues Over Firing at Yahoo
articles.snippet: With the words “I’ve just been fired,” Yahoo’s chief executive, Carol A. Bartz, did something that dismissed managers almost never do.
articles.abstract: With the words “I’ve just been fired,” Yahoo’s chief executive, Carol A. Bartz, did something that dismissed managers almost never do.

articles.headline: Rising Fears of Recession
articles.snippet: If history is a guide, the odds that the American economy is falling into a double-dip recession may have reached 50 percent.
articles.abstract: If history is a guide, the odds that the American economy is falling into a double-dip recession may have reached 50 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: If history is a guide, the odds that the American economy is falling into a double-dip recession have risen sharply in recent weeks and may even have reached 50 percent.

articles.headline: Waiting for a New Blueprint From Bank of America
articles.snippet: Top executives of the country’s largest bank will gather to review recommendations of a 44-member internal team that has been preparing restructuring plans since March.
articles.abstract: Top executives of the country’s largest bank will gather to review recommendations of a 44-member internal team that has been preparing restructuring plans since March.
articles.lead_paragraph: Brian T. Moynihan takes the stage at a Midtown Manhattan hotel on Monday to tell investors what is in store for Bank of America, but already the chief executive’s plans are generating the kind of buzz reserved for the opening of a Broadway show down the street.

articles.headline: Hit Hard by 9/11, a Piece of Queens Struggles to Let Go
articles.snippet: The terrorist attacks scythed through generations of firefighters and Wall Street traders in the largely Irish-Catholic neighborhoods on the Rockaway peninsula. Also, the neighborhood’s Muslim bagel man; and the connection between the 9/11 familie...
articles.abstract: The terrorist attacks scythed through generations of firefighters and Wall Street traders in the largely Irish-Catholic neighborhoods on the Rockaway peninsula. Also, the neighborhood’s Muslim bagel man; and the connection between the 9/11 families and wounded American soldiers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just off the boardwalk, towheaded children bounced on a blow-up trampoline. Grown-ups bantered and showed off babies. An annual charity event was starting off summer on the Rockaway peninsula, a sliver of Queens jutting into the Atlantic Ocean. In the usual place of honor, between the Budweiser and the barbecue, stood photographs of grinning young men: all childhood friends, all dead.

articles.headline: Google Details, and Defends, Its Use of Electricity
articles.snippet: Google disclosed that it continuously uses enough electricity to power 200,000 homes, but it says that in doing so, it also makes the planet greener.
articles.abstract: Google disclosed that it continuously uses enough electricity to power 200,000 homes, but it says that in doing so, it also makes the planet greener.
articles.lead_paragraph: Google disclosed Thursday that it continuously uses enough electricity to power 200,000 homes, but it says that in doing so, it also makes the planet greener.
